Message.Title: Tulips: houses, mortgages, option casinos, float jams, banksterism covered.
Message.Msg: In the planting season of 1635, as prices began to rise, there was a fundamental change in how bulbs were traded in the Netherlands. Increasingly they were sold by weight while still in the ground, with only a promissory note to indicate details of the bulb including its weight at planting and when it would be lifted. .... The bulbs themselves, the delivery of which was months away were not sold, only these paper promises. ..... Tulips grown from seed could take five to ten years to produce the flower, those from offsets from three to five years to become flowering bulbs themselves. Because a tulip bulb might produce only one or two offsets a year and then only for several years before mother bulb itself died one with offsets when lifter obviously increased in value. But a grower could not afford to sell a particularly valuable bulb too soon. To do so would limit the ability to produce any more of that variety - which is why particularly desirable bulbs always were in short supply. ...... At the height of the tulip mania, most transactions didn't even involve the exchange of goods, but became highly speculative. ..... Any payments that were made usually were at the fraction of the original price, typically less than five percent. ..... The mania did affect the social contract of the community, and the reputation of men, their credit and honor. When the market was most frenzied, it was the seller who was expected to deliver the promised goods but who often failed to do so in hope of finding a better offer. .... After the crash, it was the buyer who defaulted refusing to repay the debt or even to attend the lifting, which was the only way to verify that the bulb was the one specified by the contract. ... The perceive beauty of the flowers themselves, no doubt, was altered as well.Tulips once appreciated for their aesthetic pleasures had become commodities to be sold by the florists who could NOT deliver them to buyers who could NOT pay for them.

Message.Msg: Nor there was there any longer the desire even to plant them, rather, the bulbs were traded while still in the ground, with the dubious ownership transferred form the one speculator to another. ... 8 pigs, 4 oxen, 12 sheep, 24 tons of wheat, 48 tons of rye, 2 hogsheads of wine, 4 barrels of beer, 2 tons of butter, 1000 Lbs of cheese, a silver drinking cup and a ship! - all this for a bulb that weighted a bit more than half an ounce. Can u say ben has still ways to go.

You should try to think through the propaganda you are fed all the time. Home prices were not sustainable in 2007/2008 because "owners" did not have the income/cash flows to support them (interest only loans with no down payment....), which is why we've had so many defaults (and most of the "deleveraging" you always here about is actually default, not actual payment). Home builders have not under supplied the housing market. We had speculative demand that was out of alignment with historical norms. We also have an abundance of housing stock (lots of people have 2nd and 3 homes that could be primary homes for others if things get tight...). Plus, household formation will remain low as our youth has huge college debt (which has seniority over all other forms since it is non dischargeable), no net worth and lagging wages. Pump away...

exactly the were not sustainable at 6.5%-7% Mortgage Rates (the Fed jacked up rates to stop that) -- but they are sustainable at 4.5% mortgage rates....do the math it is quite simply. the US has the Cheapest Housing Market in the G8 -- sentiment was so beaten down it was incredible to watch... 7 years of falling prices, NObody wanted to buy into that mess... but things have turned... greed will come back. When two min. wage earnings can afford a starter condo, you have grounds for a recovery. The California market GDP is bigger than Spain and Greece Combined.... and that Economy is TURNed -- it was the first to fall and the first to comeback. Good luck - go America -- the US has everything the emerging middle class wants -- go Disney, Coke, JnJ, Rx Drugs, Credit Cards, Internet Co, Boeing, Ford, McDondalds, Starbucks.... awesome times

If the Fed had not been so aggressive, the equity tranche in the financial sector would have been wiped outand creditors would have had to bail in the sector. The moral hazard that permeates the sector would have been wiped out. The right solution is to realize losses and write off bad debt (debt restructure rather than trying to "inflate it away" through monetary policy), but the banksters would feel the pain rather than everyone else, so the Fed will do whatever it can to preserve nominal asset prices via inflation. The Fed will fail because the distribution of wealth and income makes the tax on middle and lower class families from QE food/fuel inflation overwhelm the "wealth effect" for the majority of the population. And those are the folks with the highest marginal propensity to consume, which adversely affects aggregate demand. Absent record transfer payments that fall below the radar screens of most people, we'd already be in a far darker place. We are on the cusp of the greatest loss in confidence ever, simply because the gov't has let the Fed run the show and the Fed is ONLY looking out for its bankster owners.

i don't get it. why are u getting yourself worked up because of some brainwashed individual. most of the population has been brainwashed or plain dumb and what the difference anyway. no one is really seeing the iceberg - the government spending bubble on levels is coming shortly. at the cost of property owners, of course.

Message.Title: SHORTING AMAZON-IF AMAZON LOST 25 CENTS PER SHARE NEXT QUARTER GUESS WHAT THE PRICE WOULD BE?
Message.Msg: At least $275.00 per share- jeff bezos and american funds are prime market makers the other players are small potatoes. when is amazon going to pay a dividend to shareholders?

Which is why I would only invest in real estate selectively, with an eye toward muni and state finances. It is easiest to tax things that cannot be moved... Not worked up per se but definitely frustrated that we are unwilling to do what needs to be done to restore promise and balance to our society. As long as value capture is structurally misaligned with value creation (via financial sector distortions), things will continue to get worse. We need real innovation (science based, particularly for energy) to increase efficiency and productivity. The Fed and financial sector conflate speculating in liquid tradable assets with investing in productive assets. The former is happening at the expense of the latter.

friend, i can explain. the larger size flippers wanna be who turned into investors because couldn't dump their pile of garbage on the retail home buyer are trying to package their #$%$ paper into fancy bond (circa 2004-2007) and sell it to the future baggies via blackrock help. we are talking 20-30 Mil flippers and they are all stuck in this doo doo, bleeding non stop.

New Trier tried to do a $400MM plus renovation, replete with underground parking structure for all faculty. Fortunately, there were enough of us who fought to have funding go to classrooms that it got rejected. I've got lots of kids who will attend New Trier, but I'm old school. We could tear down West and rebuild a palace for less than that... FWIW, I'd be looking for real estate in Indiana. Great state finances, still inexpensive. Can actually still generate cash flow buying around university campuses (take a page from Sam Zell...) because wealthy families with college students don't notice the rounding error of rent against tuition. Much better cash flow yield, but you need a local partner to manage it...
